lines.content: This is a project template for a greenfield Java project. It's named after the Java mascot _Duke_. Given below are instructions on how to use it.
Prerequisites: JDK 11, update Intellij to the most recent version.
1. Open Intellij (if you are not in the welcome screen, click `File` > `Close Project` to close the existing project first)
1. Open the project into Intellij as follows:
1. Select the project directory, and click `OK`.
1. If there are any further prompts, accept the defaults.
1. Configure the project to use **JDK 11** (not other versions) as explained in [here](https://www.jetbrains.com/help/idea/sdk.html#set-up-jdk).
In the same dialog, set the **Project language level** field to the `SDK default` option.

3. After that, locate the `src/main/java/duke.Duke.java` file, right-click it, and choose `Run duke.Duke.main()` (if the code editor is showing compile errors, try restarting the IDE). If the setup is correct, you should see something like the below as the output:
* Class to represent a Duke instance.
* Members include a Storage object for file I/O, a TaskList object to store
* current list of tasks and a Ui object for output to user.
* Initializes new Duke instance with associated Storage, TaskList and Ui members.
* Performs ui operations according to parsed user inputs.
* If user inputs "bye", store list of tasks and exit.
* If user inputs "list", print current tasks.
* If user inputs "mark NUMBER" or "unmark NUMBER", update the status of that task number.
* If user inputs a task, add to current tasks.
throw new DukeException("I'm sorry, but I don't know what that means :-(");
* Begins running a new Duke instance.
* Class to represent exceptions specific to Duke.
* Class to represent a parser to make sense of user command.
* Keeps track of the original input (String), the input split
* by spaces (String[]) and the command keyword (String).
* Initializes a new parser with input.
* Also splits the input on spaces and parses out the command
* as the first member of the split input array.
* Updates input (and splitInput and command) of parser.
* Returns task number (1-indexed) from parsed input.
* Tests if input has a description to instantiate a ToDo object
* by checking if input length is greater than 5.
* @return True if input has a description and false otherwise.
* Returns ToDo description by considering the input after "todo ".
* Returns Deadline description by considering the input until "/by".
* Returns Deadline date by considering the input after "/by ".
* Returns Event description by considering the input until "/from".
* Returns Event begin date by considering the input after "/from " until "/to".
* Returns Event end date by considering the input after "/to ".
* Stores file path and has methods to implement file I/O operations.
* Initializes a storage object by creating file data/duke.txt if
throw new DukeException("An error occurred while loading storage.");
* Reads and returns list of tasks from storage.
* @return ArrayList of tasks stored in data/duke.txt.
* Writes list of tasks into storage.
* @param tasks TaskList of current tasks to write to data/duke.txt.
public void store(TaskList tasks) throws DukeException {
* Deadlines are tasks that need to be done before a specific date/time.
private static final DateTimeFormatter inputFormatter = DateTimeFormatter.ofPattern("yyyy-MM-dd HH:mm");
private static final DateTimeFormatter outputFormatter = DateTimeFormatter.ofPattern("MMM dd yyyy HH:mm");
* Returns string representation of deadline date (in input format).
* This method is to be used for internal use (not for output to user) such
* @return Deadline date formatted for subsequent input.
* Events are tasks that start at a specific date/time and end at a specific
private static final DateTimeFormatter INPUT_FORMATTER = DateTimeFormatter.ofPattern("yyyy-MM-dd HH:mm");
private static final DateTimeFormatter OUTPUT_FORMATTER = DateTimeFormatter.ofPattern("MMM dd yyyy HH:mm");
public Event(String description, String from, String to) {
* Returns string representation of event begin date (in input format).
* This method is to be used for internal use (not for output to user) such
* @return Event begin date formatted for subsequent input.
* Returns string representation of event end date (in input format).
* This method is to be used for internal use (not for output to user) such
* @return Event end date formatted for subsequent input.
* Class to store duke.task description along with completion status.
* Sets task status to not done.
* If task is done, returns a space (" ").
* If task is not done, returns an "X".
return (isDone ? "X" : " "); // mark done duke.task with X
* ToDos are tasks without any date/time attached to it.

* @param i Index of the task to return.
* @return The task at the specified position in the list.
public Task getTask(int i) throws DukeException {
throw new DukeException("Unable to get duke.task.");
* Appends the specified task to the end of the task list.
* @param t Task to be appended to the list.
* Removes the task at the specified position in this list.
* Shifts any subsequent tasks in the list to the left (subtracts one from their indices).
* @param i The index of the task to be removed.
* @return The task that was removed from the task list.
public Task removeTask(int i) throws DukeException {
throw new DukeException("Unable to remove duke.task.");
* Prints a line 4 spaces away from the left edge of the screen to visually
* separate Duke's replies from user input.
* Prints Duke's greeting message (bounded by lines above and below).
System.out.printf("     %s%n", "What can I do for you?");
* Prints Duke's farewell message (bounded by lines above and below).
System.out.printf("     %s%n", "Bye. Hope to see you again soon!");
* Marks task (selected by position in list).
* @param parser Parser object to get task number.
public void markTask(TaskList tasks, Parser parser) throws DukeException {
